> >Well, with n^2 types of things, that means even P2's and above could
> >eventually get hit -- if 150 characters takes 225,000 units of time,
> >something really big like 400 guys would take 1,600,000 ...
>
> What if CL branching isn't the problem? It might be the explosions and
splash damage CL causes that's
> slowing down the system.

Possibly, it depends on how those effects are calculated and when they are
calculated.
Damage application should be straightforward (but if it's area damage it
could be expensive, possibly another n for searching through all characters
to apply damage to) and the random run function should be low cost (pick
direction, run that way) and the explosions should be very low cost
(explosion occured here, draw me).

So in the worst case, and without knowing anything about how it works, you
could be looking at n^3 cost, quite a bit worse but still not game-stopping.

> this could be tested with a thief bombing 60 people; fleeing would be the
same, in this case... if the system slows down, then it's a fault in the
"flee from explosions" function. if it doesn't, then it's a problem in the
CL target-selection function.
>

That would be interesting, can you place bombs in scenarios that go off (I
noticed a while ago that funny errors were being reported and the cause was
a rouge boomerang that was placed on it's own into the scenario)?
If you can maybe someone could produce a testing scenario, however I still
believe that each explosion would only be at worst cost n since it just goes
through every character checking if damage should be applied and they should
run somewhere.

Hmm, interesting how a programming discussion on running costs has turned
up, before it was scenario makers and now it's the programmers :)
This scenario editor will be a really interesting project, just as soon as
my exams finish :)

Cya's,
Deathifier
